awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Systems That Facilitate Cooperation and Stewardship to Improve End-User Security Behaviors
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal explores opportunities to improve cybersecurity systems by encouraging cooperation and stewardship, whereby people work together for mutually beneficial cybersecurity outcomes. For example, coworkers could provide accountability for one another in keeping their software fully up-to-date, or a trusted expert might remotely configure the security settings on a new laptop for a consenting non-expert. Many existing security systems, by contrast, are not designed to enable or encourage social interaction, a situation that often results in confusion and non-compliance. This proposal will involve studies with people to understand how and when cooperation and stewardship might be beneficial, along with the development of a platform that facilitates the evaluation and construction of such systems. The proposed work work should add to our understanding of how to design and engineer effective real-world cybersecurity systems by incorporating social interaction. Furthermore, this project will provide both undergraduate and graduate students an opportunity to participate in interdisciplinary research.
 
This proposal marries ideas from social psychology, human-computer interaction, and design to tackle a simple and timely question in usable security: How can we create systems that facilitate cooperation and stewardship in end-user cybersecurity systems in order to encourage better cybersecurity behaviors? In the context of this proposal, end-users can be thought of as people who directly interface with a security system to protect their own assets; cooperation in end-user security systems allows people to act collectively towards mutually beneficial security goals or benefit, and, stewardship in end-user security systems allow people to act on behalf of others' security goals or benefit. The union of such cooperative and stewarded systems can be said to be sociopetal, or designed to bring people together. The proposed work will encompass three interacting research thrusts: (i) running group interviews and diary studies to model end-users' day-to-day security activities and how they relate to a broader social context; (ii) developing novel sociopetal cybersecurity systems and evaluating those systems with real user groups; and, (iii) creating and releasing a platform for facilitating the development and evaluation of future sociopetal cybersecurity systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
PI Sauvik Das used this award to initiate his research agenda within the broad field of social cybersecurity as an assistant professor at Georgia Institute of Technology.

The outcomes of the effort supported by this award include a best paper honorable mention at ACM SIGCHI -- the flagship conference for human-computer interaction; three PACM HCI CSCW papers -- a top-tier venue for work that spans social computing and human-computer interaction; one SOUPS paper -- a key venue for usable privacy and security scholarship; a systematization of knowledge paper that is currently under revisions for IEEE S&P -- the flagship venue for security and privacy research; two papers currently under submission at USENIX Security -- a premier venue for security and privacy research; and, two ongoing projects that PI Das expects to submit for publication by the end of 2021.

Intellectual merits: Through the ongoing and published research supported by this award, PI Das and his students and collaborators have made the following key intellectual contributions: (i) an understanding of how small, social groups jointly navigate securing collectively owned and shared digital resources; (ii) the inadequacies of existing security and privacy controls at supporting socially nuanced S&P decision making in small group settings; (iii) a design space to scaffold the exploration and creation of social S&P controls to better support the needs of small, social groups; (iv) a model for how social triggers motivate expert-recommended S&P behaviors (e.g., enabling two-factor authentication and using a password manager) among non-experts; (v) design knowledge for how collectives of individuals might jointly author demands for redress in the face of institutional privacy violations; and, (vi) knowledge of how dynamic audience selection tools on social media services might help or hinder people in setting access control policies for content shared on social media. In addition, PI Das and his team are in the final stages of implementing and evaluating a platform designed to facilitate the rapid prototyping of social cybersecurity systems, based on the aforementioned intellectual contributions of the work supported by this award.

 

Broader impacts: PI Das has taken a number of steps to broadly disseminate the knowledge gained from conducting this work to both professional communities as well as the public-at-large. The research supported by this award has been featured in the popular press (e.g., Dark Reading), blog posts authored by PI Das, as well talks given to broad audiences of industry practitioners and academics alike in USENIX Enigma and the RSA Conference.

 

PI Das has placed a special emphasis on recruiting students from historically underrepresented backgrounds in computing in carrying out this research. Indeed, among the 22 co-authors of the aforementioned eight submitted or accepted publications that have resulted from this work, 16 are women and two are Black. Moreover, five undergraduate research assistants contributed to the work to the level where they will be / have been acknowledged as co-authors on one or more of the submitted / accepted publications.

 

Finally, the findings from the research supported by this award have been integrated into a new course on usable privacy and security that PI Das prepared and taught at Georgia Institute of Technology. Indeed, one of the three CSCW papers that have resulted from this award was initiated as as a student research project in that class.
